subject: Re: [junit] testing WebStart apps
msgSnippet: Maybe this is a philosophical response, but it seems to me that what you re describing isn t unit testing, but integration testing. That doesn t mean you

Maybe this is a philosophical response, but it seems to me that what
you're describing isn't unit testing, but integration testing.

That doesn't mean you shouldn't do it (far from it) just that trying to
do it with Junit will be more difficult.

Now, if you wanted to test what your application does when
something-that-acts-just-like-webstart calls its launch method (or
whatever), that would be a unit test, and more straightforward to
write.

One could also argue that that's a better test to write, since what you
need to test here is your code's implementation of the API, rather than
the implementation of the API.  ("Test only the code you're responsible
for")

If you find yourself answering, "Yeah, but I need to test my WebStart
configuration...", then I'd say again that configuration testing sounds
more like integration testing.  

I wish I had a recommendation for a good automated integration testing
tool, perhaps someone else can supply that?

-Kevin
--- Sean Machin <smachin@...> wrote:
> Hi All,
> 
> I'm trying to think of a good way to test some Java apps. that are
> launched by WebStart.  I've setup some basic tests with HTTPUnit
> that go to the launch page, follow each WebStart link and ensure
> that a valid JNLP file is retrieved for each simulated
> link click.  What I'd really like to do is to actually load
> each app, get past the login screen and verify each
> app's main frame is bought up without any database exceptions etc.
> 
> Can anyone advise on how best to accomplish this?
> 
> Thanks,
> Sean
> 
>
